analytic.title: החלק הראשון של "אלכתאב אלמשתמל" לאבו אלפרג' הרון ותלותו ב"כתאב אלאצול פי אלנחו" לאבו אלסראג'

biblStruct.note: This paper deals with MS. Firk. II, Evr.-Arab. I, no. 2388 from the Saltykov-Shchedrin Public Library (St. Petersburg). This manuscript contains most of Part One of al-Kitāb al-Muštamil 'alā al-'Uṣūl wa-al-Fuṣūl fī al-Luġa al-'Ibrāniyya (=The Comprehensive Book Concerning the Foundations and Branches of the Hebrew Language) by Abū al-Faraj Harūn, a very prominent Karaite grammarian who lived in Jerusalem in the second half of the eleventh century. An analysis of the text reveals that Abū al-Faraj devoted this part of his treatise to the foundations of Hebrew syntax. A comparison of this section to the writings of medieval Arabic grammarians leads to the conclusion that the greater part of Abū al-Faraj's syntactic theory was copied from Kitāb al-'Uṣūl fī al-Naḥw by the prominent Arabic grammarian Ibn al-Sarrāj (d. 928). I claim, in fact, that large sections, sometimes whole chapters, such as the one on the direct object (maf'ūl bihi), are copied word for word from Ibn al-Sarrāj. This is not merely a question of borrowed terminology or grammatical concepts
